Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: sexual-explicit and non-sexual-explicit. A comment is considered sexual-explicit if it explicitly portrays sexual matters.

It started back in 2016, when he turned repeal into an unthinking imperative.  That was a mistake born of ignorance.  He did not understand healthcare complexities.  He (and the GOP) should have heralded a more deliberate approach instead of an "immediate" "first act on first day of my Presidency" approach.

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It does not meet the elements of Indecent Exposure, which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person when done with the intent to arouse. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

Comment: As for pot, and the creation of the MCBO, the author seems to forget that the existing free-market distribution system is dominated by players who are (a) unlikely to roll over and give up their market share and profits voluntarily; and (b) are accustomed to using intimidation and physical violence to maintain their market share.
.
The Globe itself ran a long feature piece on the practical realities of the impossibility of driving organised crime out of the pot business.
.
So that makes pot a bit different from just any other product sold in an open market.  Remember that when the LCBO started, organised crime was deeply entrenched in the liquor business, too.
.
The proper role of government in a market economy is to address market failures.  MCBO may not be a perfect solution, but a Crown Corporation backed up by the police might have a better chance at displacing the existing market dominating players.
.
The author does not address that profoundly market-distorting point.

Comment: Sir, you are begging the question--that is--your conclusion is present in the premises of your argument. You are assuming what you want to prove, namely, that it is an "injustice" to not ordain women.

If God has not called women to orders, then no ordaining women is just.  It would be an injustice to ordain them.

In the second place, I define justice as giving something their due--what they are owed.  No one is owed the Sacraments. The Sacraments are gifts. Therefore I do not see how one can claim they are entitled to any of the Sacraments, let alone ordination.

In any case, in order to claim that the Church teaching on women is unjust, you have to prove that God is calling women to ordination in the first place--and THAT, sir, is the question.  THAT is what is at issue.

Comment: Some cynics among us suspect that this indeed is a major factor in the climate-change-will-kill-us-all! brohouha --- make the use of fossil fuels legally actionable, so that entities claiming "injury" by climate can sue for the Big Bucks.  :-/

It's been tried before - one of the small Pacific island nations (Vanuatu, I think) filed some sort of suit in the 1990s regarding sea level rise.  But the plaintiffs forgot (or didn't know) that the Pacific Ocean in effect sloshes back and forth in time with the ENSO to the tune of several centimeters relative sea level change per cycle.  They filed suit at a time when the relative sea level had in fact been *dropping* around their islands for several years - kind of shot themselves in the foot.  (Didn't win the case either, as I recall.)  ;-)

It will be interesting to see how the CA suits turn out.  A win would certainly help them fill the huge hole in the public pension liabilities that they face.  (The real reason for filing?)

Comment: I  belong to the last generation of Catholics who still remember the liturgy as it was before the Second Vatican Council (and who still know their Latin). I respect that liturgy for what it was and what it meant to those who came before us -- especially those who lived under persecution -- but I have no desire to return to it. The world has moved on since 1962. So has the Church.

This debate is fundamentally about ecclesiology, not liturgy. Let's weed the biretta-boys out of the seminaries and close any seminaries that are still teaching the toxic doctrine that a priest is 'ontologically superior' to a layperson.

If you were to attend Solemn Mass at The Oratory in London (where one of my uncles was a priest for 25 years), you would think you were attending a pre-Vatican II Mass. In fact, it is a modern Roman Mass celebrated in Latin with traditional ceremonial including fiddle-back chasubles, lace albs and birettas. Few Catholics under 60 would know the difference.

Comment: I am old enough.  The state forgave some of my Alaska Student Loan in exchange for me spending my weekends and evenings on my students' writing so that they could write clearly--and perhaps, therefore, think clearly.  It was a fair bargain, I hope.  I drove a crappy, cold Dodge Colt to work and burned wood for heat.  I paid Alaska State income tax.  My pension is skinny.  My mortgage is nil because I built my houses out of pocket. So I get it that some Alaskans younger than I face massive student debt and unmanageable insurance premiums, as well as stagnant wages.  But does the hardship that younger Alaskans face mean we should burn through our state's savings accounts until there's nothing left?  If we do that (call this the legislative approach) those younger Alaskans will be even worse off.  Walker did what he could with the tools the legislature--that has done precious little to fix the problem--left him.  He's the statesman, the adult in the room, whether popular or not.

Comment: A truly dispassionate computer program drawing the lines based on geographic continuity would be best.  The problem is the Voting Right Act that requires minorities to be given special treatment.  Such a computer program would probably get thrown out and we'd be back to square one.

The worst case is when we have 60-40 districts.  80-20 is actually better than 60-40, because 60-40 still means the 60 side always wins, with 40% always misrepresented.  At least when it's 80-20, only 20% are misrepresented.

50-50 is best, since it should produce a consistent stream of moderate reps from each party rotating through.  But that's very hard to accomplish such balance in more than maybe 1 or 2 districts.  Complicating it further is how to count the U's. Especially now, as the stupid law allowing U's to vote in party primaries means many true D's and R's and now registering as U's.  You simply cannot assume that most U's are in the middle anymore.

Comment: Picard - as an affected doctor let me say that you are missing an important aspect of how this negatively affects the public. 

The partnership groups that we created serve the public in a valuable way. In specialist groups such as my own, we pool all sources of income and divide it equitably among members - young and old, and with varying job descriptions. This removes disincentives to forego critical work that is poorly remunerated - including activities such as; low paying yet necessary procedures, medical school teaching, administrative work, and research. The latter pay a fraction of what more lucrative clinical activities would. 

The tax change leaves us with 3 options; 1) take a haircut   2)dissolve group arrangements so that we can each benefit from a small business tax deduction   3) reduce time spent on poorly paid activities. Our group will do 2) and 3). 

Doctors won't leave - a stupid threat from some of us only. But yet the public will lose out here.

Comment: If two thirds of Canadians do indeed support climate change action (questionable), and if it is a question of how carbon pricing is implemented rather than if (again not fully convinced), then the best proposed plan so far is Michael Chong's national revenue neutral carbon tax.  

Chong's proposal is similar to the BC model, but it is initially revenue negative as large income and corporate tax cuts come first and the carbon price rises in a gradual predictable manner.  In turn a significant amount of government overhead on green funding programs is eliminated, so that markets are left to come up with solutions given the tax signals. 

Trudeau's approach layers carbon tax on top of existing green programs, and of course his additional intervention and spending.  Don't be fooled when he says revenue neutral, as 3 of 4 provinces (so far) have opted for a tax grab.

Chong is a long shot in the CPC race.  I'd rather have no carbon tax than a poorly designed one like the Trudeau 'plan'.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: I remember the brown cloud from back in the 60's.  Some days you couldn't see the mountains from Aurora.  We fixed that with catalytic convertors, not solar.  I was in the solar business in the early 80's, and sold a ton of domestic water heating systems to reduce the use of natural gas, or in a few cases, electricity or propane.  We used charts showing how much the price of nat gas had risen since the early 70's and projected that 30 years into the future to justify the cost.  But in 1983, the deregulated price of nat gas led production to meet demand, and the price has been coming down as fast as those solar panels came off the rooftops.  There aren't any tax credits for parts and repairs on those damned things, so it wasn't worth it to fix them for the small amount it was saving on the utility bill.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Weather lies on top of climate. If the climate changes, the weather, by definition, changes with it. AGW has not been the cause of hurricanes. But hurricanes forming given AGW-forced warmer water, increased humidity, and higher sea level, result in greater damage.

I read an interesting analog today with a hypothetical, small increase in gravity. Injuries from falls would likely increase, even though falls had occurred with similar frequency before that gravimetric increase.

If the Galveston hurricane of 1900 (which, BTW, was a cat 4, just like Harvey) occurred in this "new normal" of increased global temperature, it would have likely been more destructive than it was.

Comment: I don't think there is anything wrong with acknowledging the cultural losses suffered by indigenous people resulting from what I'll call the process of discovery and acquisition. Its actually quite heartbreaking. (Drums of Diomede is a good book for perspective). I am white and I grew up in the Alaska bush.  Its a misguided idea to think that there is any need for "formulating a way to help Alaska Native culture rebound as a proud people" and I'd go as far as to say that statement is pretty harsh. Their cultural loss is staggering. Their generational cultural loss is immeasurable. There is no going back - only forward.  I learned young that "proud" is not a word I should use to describe the Alaska native - in fact, it's a bit of an insult. They are strong, intuitive, intelligent, focused, amazingly and instinctively tuned into the natural world. My experience is that they have a death grip on their culture.  Suggesting that they need help with it is a statement of ignorance.
